StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in surficial sediment samples collected Jan-Dec 1979 from coastal Washington state at 8-140 ng/g dry sediment(1) and in 49 Penobscot Bay, ME samples collected June and July1982 at 14-696 ppb dry weight(2). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was found in surficial sediments from the St. Mary's River, MI in 1985 at not detected to 67.0 mg/kg dry weight(3). Hamilton Harbor sediment cores collected in 1989 contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at concentrations of, 0-27.8, 0-11.4 and 0-4.6 ug/g at respective depths of 0-2, 2-4 and 10-12 cm(4). Bed sediments collected along a contamination gradient in the Lauritzen Canal, CA in 1993 contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at 59-1400 ng/g; the highest concentration occurring at the head of the canal(5). Bed and suspended sediment samples taken from Suisun Bay, CA contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at not detected to 34 and 34-37 ng/g dry weight, respectively(6). Mean benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in sediments from Arthur Kill, Hackensack River, Kill Van Kull, Passaic River, and Newark Bay, NJ were 1.3, 1.3, 0.92, 3.9, and 1.7 mg/kg dry weight, respectively; samples were collected Nov 1991 to March 1993(7). In 18 sediment samples collected Oct 28 to Nov 6, 2002 from 19 locations on the lower Missouri River, benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 7.0-470 ng/g dry weight(8). Seven sediment samples collected in the vicinity of a former manufactured gas plant on the Hudson River, NY contained 4.9-57.9 mg/kg of benzo(k)fluoranthene; samples were collected in 2003(9). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from 114 sites from 8 historically contaminated locations in New York and North Carolina at 0.02-418 ug/g; samples were collected 2003 to 2005(10). Pore water concentrations of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene from 51 of these samples were not detected to 2.1 ng/g(10). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from one of seven locations on Lake Erie at 0.73 mg/kg; samples were collected in Aug 2006(11). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 10.4-44.2 ng/g dry weight in 24 samples collected Aug 16-19, 2011 from the southern part of Lake Michigan(12).

Reference: (1) Tan YL, Heit M; Geochem Cosmochim Acta 45: 2267-79 (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in air samples from 6 US cities in the summer of 1958 and winter of 1959 at 0.2-4.9 and 1.7-20.0 ng/cu m, respectively(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in 4 cities in New Jersey at 0.05-3.17 ng/cu m; the lowest values were found in the summer, the highest levels were detected in the fall and winter(2). Average annual concentrations of benzo(k)fluoranthene in Hamilton, Ontario, New York City and Los Angeles were 1.46, 0.60 and 0.20 ng/cu m, respectively(3). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in Los Angeles at a site with heavy traffic and no industry at 0.03 ng/cu m(4). It is typically detected in urban fallout on the Chesapeake Bay(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in ambient air samples from Los Angeles, CA in the summer (winter) of 1974-1975 and 1981-1982 at 0.2 (0.5) and 0.2 (0.4) ng/cu m, respectively(6). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in ambient air from urban NJ in the summer and winter of 1982-1983 at 0.1-0.2 and 0.4-0.6 ng/cu m, respectively(6). Benzofluoranthenes were detected in aerosol samples from Kenmore Square, MA at 3.22 ng/cu m(7). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in the atmosphere of a city agglomeration at 0.729 and 0.206 ng/cu m(8). Ambient annual average benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in fine particles found at west Los Angeles, downtown Los Angeles, Pasadena, Rubidoux and San Nicolas Island in 1982 were 1.03, 1.15, 1.20, 0.33 and <0.01 ng/cu m, respectively(9). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in airborne particulate matter collected Dec 11-18, 1986 from two locations in Riverdale, Yukon, Canada at mean concentrations of 129 and 13 ppm(10). Air in Ontario cities contained 0.057 to 5.145 ng/cu m benzo(k)fluoranthene; the highest values were measured in the fall(11).

Reference: (1) Greenberg A; pp. 93-118 in Toxic Air Pollution, Lioy, Daisey, eds., Chelsea, MI: Lewis Publ Inc (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in atmospheric particulate matter collected in Antony (St. Denis), France in Aug 1979, Oct 1979 and Jan 1980 at concentrations of 0.12 (0.29), 3.0 (3.7) and 7.4 (25) ng/cu m, respectively(1). The mean particulate phase benzo(k)fluoranthene concentration in 62 samples collected Sept 21, 1992 to Oct 1, 1993 in urban Lahore, Pakistan was 4.61 ng/cu m(4). Mean winter particulate phase benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations at an urban site in Lahore, Pakistan and Calcutta, India were 7.73 and 22.4 ng/cu m, respectively(4). Yearly mean particulate phase benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations at an urban site in Lahore, Pakistan and Birmingham, UK were 4.61 and 0.63 ng/cu m, respectively(4). Atmospheric samples collected at locations around Birmingham, UK in the winter and summer of 1992 contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at a total concentration of 1.2 and 0.16 ng/cu m, respectively(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in air in the particulate (vapor) phase at 0.68 (0.07), 1.1 (0.08) and 2.4 (0.03) ng/cu m in South Kensington, Birmingham and Manchester, UK, respectively(6). Atmospheric benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene concentrations measured at a street in the center of Copenhagen, Denmark in 1992 and 1993 were 9.5 and 7.9 ng/cu m, respectively(7). Mean atmospheric benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene concentrations on a street, in a city park, and on a bus street in Copenhagen were 9.3, 2.9, and 1.6 ng/cu m, respectively(7). The mean benzo(k)fluoranthene concentration in ambient air samples from Kralingen and Schiedam, The Netherlands were 0.89 and 1.03 ng/cu m, respectively(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in airborne particles collected in Santiago, Chile at an annual average and range of 16.66 and 1.08-92.95 ng/cu m, respectively(9). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 4.3-23.5 ng/sq m for Santiago, Chile in 1992(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected in moderate dark roasted coffee, but was found at 0-0.8 and 70-140 ppb in dark roasted coffee and coffee soots, respectively(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in mesquite grilled beef patties at 14, 10, and 8 ug/kg for 70% lean, 80% lean, and 90% lean beef, respectively; it was not detected in hardwood charcoal grilled patties(2). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene was detected at <0.05-6.3 ug/kg fresh weight in 23 lettuce (Lactuca sativa var. crispa) samples grown in private gardens Sept 1984 in southern Finland(3). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene was detected in the following Finnish fat samples, ug/kg: 80% butter and vegetable oil mixture, 0.15; cooking margarines, 0.05-4.5; table margarines, not detected to 5.0; margarine, 7.2; cold pressed sunflower oil, 0.41; corn oil, 0.09; cold pressed corn oil, 2.5; rapeseed and turnip rapeseed oil, 0.66; soybean oil, 1.3 to 2.4; and coconut fat, 0.15; crude coconut oil, 91; and deodorized coconut oil, 1.0(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was qualitatively detected in frankfurters and Frankisch black smoked ham(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in uncooked, cooked, caned and frozen carrots, purchased from local markets, at 0.7, 1.8, 0.3 and 0.6 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(6). The core of carrots, grown in soil amended with sewage sludge, contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at <0.1-0.1 ug/kg fresh weight(7). Honey collected May-Oct 2007 from eight sample locations in Italy did not contained benzo(k)fluoranthene (detection limit 0.01 ng/g wet weight)(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected in Chinese cabbage (Brassica parachinensis, paitsai (Brassica chinensis), water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica), edible amaranth (Amaranthus tricolor), mustard (Brassica juncea), lettuce (Loctuca satira), asparagus bean (Vigna sesquipedalis), shallot (Allium asclonicum), Chinese chive (Allium tuberosum), balpear (Momordica charantia) or cucumber (Cucumis sativus) samples collected from nine farms located in the Pearl River Delta, South China(9). StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure may be through inhalation and dermal contact with benzo(k)fluoranthene at workplaces where coal and petroleum derived substances are produced or used or where combustion processes are extensive(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in breathing zones of a plant producing carbon anodes for aluminum electrolysis at 0.12-4.32 ug/cu m(2). The mean benzo(k)fluoranthene concentration in the breathing zone of workers of a creosote impregnation plant was 0.01 ug/cu m; in a hall where switch elements were assembled was 0.2 ug/cu m; and 0.64 ug/cu m in air near manual metal-arc welding(3). Benzo(k)fluoranthene has been detected in occupational environments at the following airborne concentrations (geometric mean), ug/cu m: coke plant, 2.30; carbon anode plant, 1.003; graphite plant, 0.074; silicon carbide plant, 0.015; metal recycling plant, 0.045; and a bitumen paving plant, 0.008(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in the air of upper and lower floors of a Swedish alloy factory at an average of 160 and 69 ng/sample in samples collected Nov-Dec 2007 and at 240 and 140 ng/sample in samples collected Jan 2008(5). In Norwegian aluminum plant benzo(k)fluoranthene and benzo(b)fluoranthene constitute 0.8% of the total polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons which typically range from 1 to 4000 ug/cu m(6). The general population may be exposed to benzo(k)fluoranthene primarily through the smoking of tobacco, inhalation of polluted air and by ingestion of food and water contaminated by combustion effluents(1).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

The lists are ordered by relevancy as indicated by count of publications and other statistics, with the most relevant mentions appearing at the top.

The Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) tree for this entity.  MeSH is a controlled and hierarchically-organized vocabulary produced by the National Library of Medicine.

ChEBI Ontology tree.  ChEBI is an acronym for Chemical Entities of Biological Interest, which is a freely available dictionary of molecular entities focused on 'small' chemical compounds. ChEBI incorporates an ontological classification, whereby the relationships between molecular entities or classes of entities and their parents and/or children are specified.

Classification of this compound, provided by ChemIDplus, which is a free web search system that provides access to the structure and nomenclature authority files used for the identification of chemical substances cited in National Library of Medicine (NLM) databases.  ChemIDplus groups chemicals based on the source locators (i.e., what information resources have data for a given chemical).

CAMEO chemical reactivity classification from CAMEO Chemicals, which is a database of hazardous chemical datasheets that emergency responders and planners can use to get response recommendations and predict hazards (e.g., explosions or toxic fumes).

The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, and health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures.

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's CPDat (Chemical and Products Database).  This database contains information mapping more than 49,000 chemicals to a set of terms categorizing their usage or function in 16,000 consumer products (e.g. shampoo, soap) types based on what chemicals they contain.
A classification from the NORMAN Suspect List Exchange, which serve as a central access point to find lists of chemicals with environmental concerns.

CCSbase is an integrated platform that contains collision cross section data for the compound.  The CCSbase classification groups the compounds by the type of adduct ions that can be formed from them (e.g., [M-H]-, [M+H]+, [M+Na]+, [M+K]+).

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) database. Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
